column1: ESTJ	I'm sure there are plenty of people in this world that don't like me because of my personality type
column2: but in my case I've found the key factor is weather people are F's or T's.  Every single one of my friends is a T.  My husband is an INTP
column3: which actually works out incredibly well.  He sort of needs someone to "do the things he doesn't like to do"
column4: like planning and cleaning the house
column5: and I really need to have someone who listens to me and gives me great advice
column6: he is great at creating a big picture plan
column7: and I'm good with the details.  Now F's on the other hand
column8: I can barely understand you guys.  It really stinks because 75% of women are F's
column9: so most of my friends are men.  I do have a few girlfriends but many of them just have a hard time with how I will basically tell it like it is and I'm not very concerned with their "feelings".

column1: ESTJ	I think that lots of F's take everything I say too personally
column2: I'm generally not trying to offend them.  Think of Dr. Tempe Brennan on Bones
column3: she just says things that are true sometimes even if others find them insensitive
column4: I can't even understand why people would be offended by my pointing out the truth about something.

column1: ESTJ	It's also challenging to be a ESTJ female
column2: because I want to be in control of situations but on the other hand I also want to be feminine and believe in a traditional female role for me in my family.  This can definitely be a challenge for me to balance.  Now about the stereotypes:

column1: ESTJ	-controlling - Yes
column2: I am this way.  Especially when I think that others are incompetent
column3: if someone has earned my trust and I'm managing them I will let them do whatever they want
column4: but earning my trust isn't super easy.

column1: ESTJ	-Authoritarian -Yes
ESTJ	-Lacking in imagination (Yes and no
column2: I'm good at coming up with creative solutions to problems
column3: but I'm the kind to sit around "imagining a different world" like my INTP
column4: or even one to be very artsy/creative.)

column1: ESTJ	-Bullying - I am not a bully.  I don't pick on people or say mean things about them for no reason.  I may tell someone the truth.  For instance
column2: if someone is perpetually late I might say "It would be helpful if you could show up on time"
column3: but I don't just attack people because I think they're weak or anything.

column1: ESTJ	-Overly Competitive - Not really
column2: I like to win
column3: but I lose pretty well too

column1: ESTJ	-Can't Admit It When They're Wrong - I am addicted to finding to concrete truth
column2: and I admit being wrong pretty easily
column3: although usually I'll want some time on my own to think about things before admitting I was wrong.

column1: ESTJ	About Angry ESTJ:

ESTJ	When I was a teen I had grown up in the kind of household where people yell and scream at each other every day.  As a result I also had an anger management problem.  I had a hard time dealing with conflict in any way and would often end up yelling or getting mad.  At some point I decided I had crossed a line and decided to change.  I gradually learned to control my anger and I can't think of a single time I have yelled or screamed at anyone since I've been at an adult.  If an ESTJ you know is yelling at people it is because they can't see how much it is damaging themselves and their own lives
column2: and they don't know how to deal with the intense emotions that we feel about things.  I believe in things incredibly strongly
column3: my beliefs are not a passing fancy
column4: they make up my whole person and each day I strive to make sure I'm living by them.  If you're brave enough
column5: maybe you should mention to one of these friends that they're anger is mostly damaging them
column6: not others
column7: and that others lose respect for them when they get angry.  When I learned that
column8: it was easy for me to change.

column1: ESTJ	Also
column2: yes we are selfish
column3: actually I think all people are
column4: but that's another story :).  It is incredibly hard for me to emphasize with the hardships of others if I don't know them personally.  I can only see rational arguments.  For instance
column5: when I watch one of those commercials for dying children in africa I truly do believe it's sad....but I also cannot believe that blindly giving aid to them is the solution.  Clearly to me the solution is helping their country by bringing in industry
column6: business
column7: and jobs.  The way that the US was built.  Giving people bare necessities does not bring them into independence
column8: it only makes them believe the way to get aid is by staying poor.  Call me insensitive
column9: but the US didn't become the wealthiest country in the world by accepting charity
column10: and I'm not sure we would have if we had had charity.  I'm not saying I don't like charities
column11: but they are always the ones where people help themselves... like scholarships for academic excellence
column12: or if I hear of someone who has escaped from Cuba and made it to the US
column13: I want to take them in.  Anyway
column14: I'm not saying that I can't understand the plight of sick children
column15: but if we spent half as much money building up power plants in Africa as we did on feeding them
column16: I think the difference would be more substantial and lead to the only life I can see as worth living
column17: the one where you are financially independent.

column1: ESTJ	A few things stood out to me as being atypical of an ESTJ.  First of all
column2: you're too abstract for an S.  It seems to me your thinking on these issues and relationships are anything but grounded and concise.  Your tangents on yelling and the dilemma on whether or not to give aid to Africa are two examples of inductive logic--expounding on a smaller example into the larger issues involved.  Inductive logic is often preferred by Idealist/NF's
column3: as is your focus on relationships and people.  Guardians (SJ's) prefer linear ways of thinking which would avoid taking on such tangential topics.

column1: ESTJ	Moreover
column2: Guardians don't often understand and get along well with NT Rationals (e.g. your husband)
column3: and
column4: though of course two mature individuals of any temperament make a successful marriage work
column5: SJ/NT marriages tend to be fraught with misunderstandings and an inability to relate to one another which makes mutual satisfaction difficult to achieve.  If you are finding things work out splendidly with your NT husband
column6: and without much effort
column7: then I question your personality test results.

column1: ESTJ	David Keirsey (also an INTP
column2: btw
column3: like your husband) studied the Myers Briggs and found several weaknesses.  In particular
column4: he found that Myers-Briggs test is not very accurate in terms of measuring N vs. S.  I would recommend that you take the Keirsey temperament sorter and see if you get the same results as your MB test.

column1: ESTJ	Moreover
column2: I would add that NF Idealists (I am one myself) are more prone than any other temperament to get false results on personality sorters.  Besides the flaws of the test
column3: we are too good at understanding what the question is getting at
column4: and too self-effacing to understand ourselves in terms of absolutes.  I took MB three times and never got an accurate result.  The first result said I was ISFP
column5: the second ESFJ
column6: and the third was also a Guardian.  But I am an ENFP
column7: no doubt about it.

column1: ESTJ	I believe you regarding the E and J
column2: so I would likely peg you as ENFJ.  It's funny that you think of the world in terms of T's and F's and I think you are an F yourself.  But perhaps the T/F difference that you are referring to is actually the N/S dichotomy. According to Keirsey
column3: about 80% of the population is S
column4: consistent with your breakdown of 75% of women being hard for you to understand.  Keirsey pins the N/S dichotomy as the most important one for temperaments--the one that breaks the world down into groups of people you understand vs. groups of people you don't understand.

column1: ESTJ	N's are the abstract folk--the one's who can take an idea and get so fully absorbed in it that they can lose awareness of their surroundings.  It would be easy to think of N's as thinkers in that way.  But the T/F dichotomy refers only to the subject of interest: T's prefer to think about things
column2: F's prefer to contemplate people
column3: relationships
column4: etc.

column1: ESTJ	Keirsey's book Please Understand Me II is wonderful
column2: much more clear and compelling than his website
column3: although the website is also good.  He helps clarify many of the misunderstandings caused by Myers-Briggs mistakes and clear up much the confusion as to who we are and why we do what we do.

column1: ESTJ	BTW
column2: if you are an ENFJ married to an INTP
column3: you would be in what Keirsey found empirically was the best sort of compatibility within marriage--same with regards to N/S
column4: complementary in every other respect.  He found these sorts of marriages--Idealists/Rationalists and Guardian/Artisan--were more successful than any other matches.

column2: as a person I got along with her quite well

column4: couldn't type her

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by bluevideogame   You are very insightful ESTJ! Nice. The challenge for ESTJ is to avoid micromanaging family members. They are a powerful business force
column2: and one of the best providers for their family and society. Keep up the good work.    I spent most of my life shutting people out of my life for not measuring up or feeling the need to "teach people lessons" (so that they think more like me)
column3: I learned little pieces along the way like keeping my mouth shut when friends asked for advice because all that ended up happening was both of us getting frustrated and I would look at them differently
column4: or working hard to let the smaller broken values and principles go with friends or family
column5: but the kicker for me was when my 11 year old niece (at the time) who I am very close with had a very dramatic breakdown 5+ years ago because she felt that I would "make fun" of her haircut. So I 100% agree that micro-managing individuals
column6: namely family
column7: close friends or partners is a struggle but one worth working at.

column1: ESTJ	What might be hard for others to understand is that
column2: in my case
column3: I do it because I care for them. Because I love them. Because I want them to be happy. It isn't about controlling every single thing in the universe. I don't want people to make fun of my niece because of her hair
column4: or because of her hygiene routine (or lack thereof at the time). That would be hurtful to her. What I didn't realize was that there comes a time where I have to step back because I'm the one that's hurting the people I care about.

column1: ESTJ	I am very lucky to be surrounded by family
column2: friends
column3: and a significant other that I truly feel understand me
column4: most of the time
column5: and in a lot of cases can find humour and the silver lining within my behaviour (having a good problem solver around can be helpful!). As I've gotten older I've found being humble and brutally honest about myself and my short comings with others
column6: can sometimes endear my obsessive personality to them. I try very hard to open the doors of communication with people that I encounter in what can be stressful areas of my life (like work) so that if I become too overbearing they feel as though they can speak up about it. column1: ESTJ	I was pondering recently what the 'genius' of the SJ type was...

ESTJ	I've always defined intelligence (perhaps myopically) as not so much the ability to memorize facts and manipulate data but the ability to make meaningful connections between ideas and see big picture implications. Doing rote math problems may take some mental discipline but it means nothing intellectually unless you understand the underlying real-world implications of the numbers and variables. Even Einstein despised (but knew the importance of) doing straight math in favor of pondering the more theoretical. Though those are attributes of iNtuitives and I may have an N bias or more likely
column2: a lack of understanding of the Sensing mind and its abilities.

column1: ESTJ	For example
column2: this is excerpt from the description of weak Te.    This person easily believes in facts and figures
column3: often turn a deaf ear to everything but these. Keeps to places where he knows what to do in every situation. Suggestible by the external order of things
column4: which is often the order that was in place during his upbringing: the political system
column5: social norms
column6: etc. Always moves in the direction of highest order and carefully avoids chaos
column7: is inspired by this order and worries that in future it might change. Knowledge of the facts of the situation often replaces true understanding of the underlying problems. Understanding becomes superficial
column8: simply a collection of surface data and statistics
column9: laws and regulations. He does not like long and detailed explanations
column10: will immediately interrupt and say: "So what is this in actuality?". He wants to get a working solution or order right away
column11: not the rationale behind it. Likes terminology
column12: you can sometimes talk to him only using some accepted terms and this will be sufficient. Especially gets influenced by the facts that he sees with his own eyes or can touch with own hands. Thus he can fall victim to scams that provide specious claims and facts
column13: especially if the scam is done out in the open ("simple dexterity of hands and no tricks").

column3: what's one difference you would make that would impact the atmosphere? Or make service faster? Or make it possible that baby dragons can handle all delivery service needs?    I'm wondering how improving efficiency and figuring out how to make things work is Ne not Te?

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by EmmaGilbert   I'm wondering how improving efficiency and figuring out how to make things work is Ne not Te?    It's not. You've misread what I wrote.
ESTJ	Put simply
column2: Ne is the horse
column3: Te the rider.

column1: ESTJ	Ne's brainstorming process guided and condensed by Te into a final
column2: best solution. Te doesn't come up with the various ideas; it simply identifies the best from among the many. Si confirms or confronts Te's conclusion
column3: and Fi justifies it or condemns it morally.

column1: ESTJ	For example
column2: say you asked me to think of ways to smuggle a knife into a prison.

column1: ESTJ	Ne creates the various possibilities (smuggle it baked in bread
column2: put it in a book with a cutout in the pages
column3: deliver through a corrupt guard
column4: fly it by drone over the prison walls).

column1: ESTJ	Te refines the possibilities (bread probably gets screened
column2: book's already been done
column3: guard leaves a witness).

column1: ESTJ	Si confirms or denies Te's results.
ESTJ	Fi justifies or condemns the final solution (Harry really needs that knife to fight off his prison enemies).
ESTJ	Note: In this scenario
column2: Te would normally go first and ask "is smuggling the knife in even feasible?" or details like "what kind of prison/how many guards/what kind of security/etc" but this is a hypothetical and I'm pretending that I'm required to answer.

column1: ESTJ	I get burnt out spending too much time with people. I'm not much of one for initiating hanging out with others

column1: ESTJ	My social life tends to be pretty segregated too
column2: like I've got friends I hang out with in groups because it's fun and we can party
column3: then I have the friends I hang out with one on one or maybe 3 of us (who are usually my closer friends)
column4: there's acquaintances... People I know through organizations I'm a member or volunteer with that I only see there
column5: classmates (99% of them I don't hang out with outside of school) and workmates (same deal).

column1: ESTJ	Among the people I wouldn't hang out with outside of where we met
column2: I can apparently appear pretty reserved and uninterested in forming stronger relationships... it's not intentional
column3: but it pretty much is how I feel so I guess that works out.

column1: ESTJ	Regardless

column3: but it's not a rule they be the same.

She said in this world there are people who are the drones and just do what they are told or need to do without like consulting or really looking into it. And its needed its necessary but its not me and its not good for me. So what works for you wont work for me and vice versa. I just want you to trust me in what I say and not take it the wrong way since others on here have been..........closed minded. My advice is just advice and its just me being helpful and nice because well i care to a fault XP. So you can be open and trust me on that :3

column7: not all the time. But when I am
column8: you feel it. At least that's what it seems like when I see people react to me.

column1: ESTJ	Do not give affection to people that do not give back unless doing so gets you something you appreciate other than being reciprocated.

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by Miyu   How can you tell the difference between ESTJs and ISTJs?    Ask yourself which one is more likely to run you over if you stand in their way. That's the ESTJ. ISTJs are much more cautious and self-doubting
column2: and tend to far more passive. Three of my best friends are ISTJs- they're extremely organized
column3: but they aren't much good at organizing other people. ESTJs motivate groups and organize projects
column4: while ISTJs motivate themselves and organize themselves. As they grow older
column5: many ISTJs do learn how to work with groups
column6: but their natural preference is only a few people
column7: while ESTJs like a much larger group to work with
column8: and will often take a leadership role. I'm an ENTJ
column9: and the ESTJs I know appear far more extraverted than I am. Last week my ESTJ friend and I went shopping
column10: and she brought four of our other friends with us when I thought it would just be the two of us. ISTJs are far more likely to just go with the flow and follow along unless something is really wrong. They conserve their energy more.      Originally Posted by Whitewolf   Hi everyone! column1: ESTJ	How was your life between the age of about... 1 to 12 in general? Where there any specialy instances that seemed Te to you? How was your interaction with other children? How curious were you? How did you complete your tasks and how did you do at school? What were your hobbies and are there any interesting things that you want to mention?

ESTJ	To give an example for the last one: I used to "bake" a lot of "cakes" when I was 4 or 5. I just threw together things that could theoretically be made into a cake and added other ingredients that I wanted to have in it. Then
column2: I just baked it and was always happy that I created something
column3: although they were hardly ever edible.

column1: ESTJ	Also
ESTJ	@TopCatLSD
column2: if he wants ^^

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by Tsubaki   Also
ESTJ	@TopCatLSD
column2: if he wants ^^    Man
column3: I was a fuckin idiot when I was a kid. My parents used too worry about my health a lot.

column1: ESTJ	When I was a baby still sleeping in the crib
column2: my parents had given me my own room and put me right next to the window. Apparently I used to climb out of the crib and onto the window sill and stare outside
column3: my parents found me dangling my feet out the window trying to escape (<thanks mom & dad) I did it so often that they eventually gave my room to my sis and made me sleep in their room so they could supervise me. When I was little I also had a habit of hiding in my house until my parents would cry cause they thought they lost me
column4: then I'd burst out like "SURPRISE BITCH!!"

column1: ESTJ	When I started going to school
column2: I was constantly one of the most obnoxious kids in the class room. I was constantly making noise and trying to make my classmates laugh. My teachers hated me. Looking back I was probably a huge disappointment to me ESFJ dad
column3: he always wanted us to be the most successful out of everyone in our peer group
column4: but I would fail every academic subject and couldn't for my life concentrate in the classroom. I was also really possessive of girls I had crushes on (I think I still am
column5: actually) if I saw any guy talking to them
column6: I'd jump in and be like "Uh
column7: no bitch! She's mine."

column1: ESTJ	My 12 year old life was probably the darkest point in my life. I was part of an underground fight club with me and my main group of friends. I was cool with the skater table
column2: the black table
column3: and the beaner table <well
column4: the NOT as ghetto beaner table. (I'm hispanic
column5: I can say that). We used to get like thirty people at a time to show up and watch our fights
column6: it was so much fun. We used to plan fights like a day ahead of time and text out witch bathroom or hallway we where going to host it in. My job was to "charm" the campus supervisors into letting us go into the most empty parts of school
column7: I'd say "We need to go to Mr.Whatshisfaces room
column8: we'll be quick" or my favorite "Oh campus supervisor #2 I almost didn't notice you got your hair done
column9: it looks nice!" Cause there was so many of us
column10: we had to brake into squads and use different paths to get their
column11: my squad always had the easiest getting in. We also had a Youtube channel where we would post the fights
column12: but it got taken down by the cops...

column1: ESTJ	After that was over I got to go home to my bipolar INFP mum whom I was living with; I'll spare the details. My parents where going through divorce
column2: so all she could afford was a broken down piece of shit house with cockroaches and a falling roof. She would come home every night sobbing her eyes out
column3: depressed. It was my responsibility to care for her emotionally. It felt like I was parenting her
column4: and not the other way around. I legit feel sorry for any parents who have INFP kids
column5: It's absolutely miserable.

column1: ESTJ	^So if you're noticing a trend
column2: I was an incredibly Se heavy kid who grew up in an Ne-Fe heavy world.

column1: ESTJ	I usually had heaps of new ideas as a kid and I also liked to show them to other people. I managed to get many introverts very excited when they were playing with me. Being alone was also fine for me
column2: though. I always did some crazy things like creating my own vending machine that gives out marbles (as far as I remember
column3: I got several things stuck in the radiator when doing this) and I mixed together every kind of soap and shampoo that I found
column4: hoping that something cool would happen. I was also really energetic and happy at that time. My great-grandpa once told my grandma: "This kid isn't able to walk normally." She asked why he thought that and he responded: "She takes two steps and every third one is a jump" I remember that I was always very interested in science and my dad teached me how electricity works and gave me plugboards with all sorts of stuff to experiment with. I also had a book about it but I usually just tried my own stuff. (I also had a chemistry set and I tried to grow crystals for some time)

column1: ESTJ	I hated my kindergarden because the people were boring and never let me do what I wanted. The girls weren't very nice although I had a few female friends and I just liked to play with some of the boys. Also
column2: I frequently threw tantrums at that age because I was indecisive and someone forced me to decide. During elementary school
column3: I had two very good friends and also got along with the rest of the class. Our school was a bit alternative and we were able to do whatever we wanted whenever we wanted as long as we finished everything until the end of the day.

column1: ESTJ	I was at an after-school care club for one year and I totally hated it because of the same reasons
column2: I hated kindergarden. I usually just played with an ENTJ girl who was pretty bossy and sometimes hard to cope with.

column1: ESTJ	The start of middle school wasn't hard for me in terms of school work but there was one girl that heavily bullied another girl. I was in a rather introverted phase but I still decided to call her out for it - I don't even know why... Then
column2: that girl also tried to make me look bad which was just... kind of irritating but I didn't really care.

column1: ESTJ	My parents got divorced when I was 13 or something and it really hurt me
column2: although I didn't show it. For almost a year
column3: I sucessfully hid it
column4: just because I didn't want pity from anyone. In addition to that
column5: my ENFJ mum wanted to make everything more structured and started to give me restrictions.(I was able to decide almost everything on my own before that and it worked) I fought a lot with her and I often got into even worse situations because it's hard to discuss with someone who isn't willing to listen to other opinions.

column1: ESTJ	Since the start of highschool
column2: I'm more open again and I made lots of friends. I also think that I can cope with emotions way better now ^^

column1: ESTJ	Since the start of highschool
column2: I'm more open again and I made lots of friends. I also think that I can cope with emotions way better now ^^    Copy that
column3: here we go. (I'm probably going to include some stuff after 12/13 as well
column4: as it's relevant to the story.

column1: ESTJ	For a starter
column2: I wanted to know how everything worked. And I wanted to know the reason why I had to do stuff. (This one was important
column3: though it didn't really work well with ESFJ mother). Say why I had to eat with both fork and knife
column4: if I don't use the knife
column5: why would I have to have it in my hand? Why do I have to take of my shoes when it's dry outside and they aren't dirty? Why can't I go outside with just socks if they don't get dirty? I wanted answers on all of those questions
column6: and I wanted the answers to make sense
column7: so it really frustrated me when I got the answer "that's how you do it" or answers similar to that.

column1: ESTJ	Another problem that arose is rather connected to inferior Fi than Te
column2: but still. The general thing is that I wasn't always considerate to how other people would perceive what I was saying
column3: so they got hurt. Best example I can think of is ones when my sister had a new cap
column4: and well
column5: I didn't think it fit her. So I told her so. She took it badly
column6: and yea. My mom tried to explain to me that I shouldn't do stuff like that
column7: but I just told her what I thought as a matter of fact.

column1: ESTJ	I didn't really have any problem in school
column2: until I was about 11/12. Before that I enjoyed it
column3: I was good at what we did
column4: I learnt stuff (I've always wanted to learn interesting things
column5: though I have a hard time putting down the energy and time if I don't enjoy it or find it useful
column6: from when I was young 'til this day)
column7: and had lots of friends. After that though
column8: we started having English as a "real" subject
column9: (which didn't work out for me until maybe 14/15
column10: where I went from lowest to among the highest grades)
column11: and I "noticed" that I didn't really have any friends. Well
column12: I had friends to hang out with in school
column13: but I guess that's where my Fi went in and said that that wasn't enough
column14: and I wanted "more" than just that. So during the latter half of elementary school
column15: I went through without having any real friends.

column1: ESTJ	Later (13/14
column2: but relevant as I started developing my Te more here (I think))
column3: I used to get in to a lot of fights with my mom
column4: and looking at it from now
column5: I see that it's mostly Te/Fe. (also just teenager/parent
column6: but influenced by the functions) As I always wanted things to make sense
column7: and she didn't give me a reason for things but still forced them upon me

column1: ESTJ	I haven't had any problems with other kids in my age that I can think of. And Te wasn't that obvious either. Probably since I was raised in a very non-Te way by my ENFP dad and ESFJ mom. I was always taking the more submissive part in relations I entered
column2: which I didn't always like
column3: but that's how I worked at that time
column4: so that's what I did.

column1: ESTJ	When I was between five and about 12
column2: most of my spare time was spent outside
column3: making swords of sticks and wood and bow and arrow
column4: and then playing with those in a made-up world. Sometimes
column5: I could even stop playing for half an hour or so
column6: just to think of the back-story of who I was
column7: the world around him
column8: etc. I've always enjoyed making things myself
column9: and have a couple of padded swords I made just half a year ago
column10: for more "realistic" fighting. So I guess that interest has always been there

column1: ESTJ	Another thing I loved was Lego
column2: and making things myself (not according to the design
column3: but how I wanted it to be).

column1: ESTJ	Another thing that might be of interest is that when I became old enough to start helping with cleaning the house and stuff
column2: I pretty fast came to the conclusion that I had to have the responsibility for some part of it
column3: as it didn't work when my parents said "do this
column4: do that".

column1: ESTJ	I think I was less typical Te than I am now
column2: though it was there
column3: hidden underneath. I just wasn't comfortable to expose it until I changed school (elementary school wasn't that good
column4: and people weren't accepting of Te at all...)

column1: ESTJ	Hey there
ESTJ	I have many questions:
ESTJ	1- Let's say you're a parent and your child is grown up. If your child's room is a mess
column2: and you ask them to clean it but they don't or they clean it but it's still considered a mess in your eyes
column3: how would you react?

column1: ESTJ	2- Are ESTJs hoarders?
ESTJ	3- What do you think of the Intuitive types? And INTJs?
ESTJ	4- You just found out that your 21 years old daughter has been in a relationship for 2 years with a guy who doesn't fit your norms (for example
column2: you're Christian and he's Atheist
column3: he has long hair
column4: he's in a band
column5: etc...)
column6: how do you react (despite her age)?

column1: ESTJ	If your daughter runs away with that guy
column2: what would you do?

column1: ESTJ	Or if she has a friend with flamboyant red hair?
ESTJ	(Anything that doesn't fit your rules/norms).
ESTJ	Can you please answer the same questions if the person is an unhealthy ESTJ?
ESTJ	Thank you
ESTJ	How do you act around a person you like? This is in regards to a friend or being smitten with.

ESTJ	I usually had heaps of new ideas as a kid and I also liked to show them to other people. I managed to get many introverts very excited when they were playing with me. Being alone was also fine for me
column2: though. I always did some crazy things like creating my own vending machine that gives out marbles (as far as I remember
column3: I got several things stuck in the radiator when doing this) and I mixed together every kind of soap and shampoo that I found
column4: hoping that something cool would happen. I was also really energetic and happy at that time. My great-grandpa once told my grandma: "This kid isn't able to walk normally." She asked why he thought that and he responded: "She takes two steps and every third one is a jump" I remember that I was always very interested in science and my dad teached me how electricity works and gave me plugboards with all sorts of stuff to experiment with. I also had a book about it but I usually just tried my own stuff. (I also had a chemistry set and I tried to grow crystals for some time)

column1: ESTJ	I hated my kindergarden because the people were boring and never let me do what I wanted. The girls weren't very nice although I had a few female friends and I just liked to play with some of the boys. Also
column2: I frequently threw tantrums at that age because I was indecisive and someone forced me to decide. During elementary school
column3: I had two very good friends and also got along with the rest of the class. Our school was a bit alternative and we were able to do whatever we wanted whenever we wanted as long as we finished everything until the end of the day.

column1: ESTJ	I was at an after-school care club for one year and I totally hated it because of the same reasons
column2: I hated kindergarden. I usually just played with an ENTJ girl who was pretty bossy and sometimes hard to cope with.

column1: ESTJ	The start of middle school wasn't hard for me in terms of school work but there was one girl that heavily bullied another girl. I was in a rather introverted phase but I still decided to call her out for it - I don't even know why... Then
column2: that girl also tried to make me look bad which was just... kind of irritating but I didn't really care.

column1: ESTJ	My parents got divorced when I was 13 or something and it really hurt me
column2: although I didn't show it. For almost a year
column3: I sucessfully hid it
column4: just because I didn't want pity from anyone. In addition to that
column5: my ENFJ mum wanted to make everything more structured and started to give me restrictions.(I was able to decide almost everything on my own before that and it worked) I fought a lot with her and I often got into even worse situations because it's hard to discuss with someone who isn't willing to listen to other opinions.

column1: ESTJ	Since the start of highschool

column2: similar to INFPs. Difference is that they have a different method and way of understanding others. column1: ESTJ	From what I can see with my dad
column2: stress causes him to get very creative in pessimistic thinking: everything will be interpreted in the worst possible way. For example
column3: our family bought lately
column4: even though second hand
column5: a very expensive vehicle. My brother arranged most of the deal and purchase
column6: but was quite surprised when he paid a part in advance and learned that there was still an extra amount VAT to be paid. He concluded that he had misunderstood the dealer
column7: especially when thinking afterwards of what the man had said. My father on the other hand (who had never talked with or seen the man)
column8: felt that the seller was trying to deceive us. When later on there seemed to be a problem with the brakes (because it had stood too long still)
column9: this idea was enforced and he was angry with my brother for not being more firm enough towards the seller. However
column10: my brother who had made the contact with the dealer knew enough to trust the man and indeed
column12: the seller paid for all the extra repairs without too much fuss. I'm not saying it's wrong to be cautious
column13: but for my dad the worst possible interpretation was the reality and he was upset towards others for not seeing this. I'm sure not all ESTJ's are this way and I should add that he is also chronicly ill and therefore more prone to stress.

ESTJ	Originally Posted by Scarlet.Black   How does your Fi effect your life? :)    My dad is an ESTJ and he goes through relationships the same way I go through sensory stimuli when I'm stressed, and he can be extremely sensitive about his values when I challenge them extensively (as in pulling out the corner stone and tearing down every counter argument, in an attempt to see where it'll take us) with logic.
ESTJ	Originally Posted by Caustic Banana   My dad is an ESTJ and he goes through relationships the same way I go through sensory stimuli when I'm stressed, and he can be extremely sensitive about his values when I challenge them extensively (as in pulling out the corner stone and tearing down every counter argument, in an attempt to see where it'll take us) with logic.    Constantly challenging someones view or value is extremely draining and unnecessary in our eyes. With Fi included, this can make us.......not be around you. We dont mind a challenge, constantly doing it is going over the line though. With inferior Fi, it can be hard to express this while someone like INFP or ISFP will express this immediately and just.......drop you. Values are not something to be logically explained; it just is and whoever doesnt like it has to deal with it. We can only explain why we value it, nothing more, nothing less. Ex: I value babies. Why? because they are cute, intelligent, full of potential, interesting, strong, adorable, and loving. When you love them, they give love in return and you know its genuine and your love will be returned. Thats it. That being said, goodluck trying to get an INFP, ISFP to share their values lol.

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by SnowSun   Can ESTJ survive and maintain a long distance relationship? Do you have any experience about this? column1: ESTJ	So the question is kind of: how do you battle restlessness
column2: when do you experience anxiety
column3: and what are you afraid of.    For me personally:

column1: ESTJ	Restlessness - This usually happens when I'm stuck in a group setting or having to converse with people that I cannot find common ground with (Ex: differing tastes in music that I have no idea about)-- it doesn't challenge me logically/intellectually so I become really restless. I just kind of let it be-- I allow myself just to be bored if I can't leave the situation or find someone else to converse with. If I'm alone
column2: usually I'll find a friend to go do something with or do something that I enjoy alone.

column1: ESTJ	Anxiety - As rare as it is
column2: I recognize this happens when I feel like I do not have control over my emotions or something triggers a negative emotional response that I don't necessarily want to voice/talk about. But I've recognized this is just a part of life/feelings.

column1: ESTJ	Afraid of - Losing all the important people around me: family mostly. Other than that
column2: I'm not afraid of much. Perhaps heights? But I don't think that's what you mean.

column2: I don't know the story in detail. Actually I would like to know more but he asked me to give some time and then he will explain.

column1: ESTJ	Well
column2: as an ENFJ this was a little bit difficult relationship for me
column3: actually too harsh ;) but he showed a lot of enthusiasm and I also liked him and had feelings for him so I continued. Then one day we had a heated up conversation on a topic he brought up which I felt insulted and reacted strictly and somehow emotionally that hurt him. To me it was not hurting. If he could have put himself in my shoes
column4: he would have told me far worse! Anyway... a few hours later I apologized for making him upset. He responded nicely but again sent me a video which I found again disturbing. That brought the next round of fight but this time in a passive way! He called me and I did not respond as I was really mad of him. Next day I asked him to meet and resolve the issue but this time he said it would be better to give time and meet later. Meantime he had a trip to visit his family and when he came back again there was no sign of him. I told myself I will text him for the last time and if he does not reply I will let it go. This time he replied with delay but we met and resolved most of the issues that bothered both of us. In the end he told me that he would have liked to continue this relationship but right now he is looking for a new job position which is not sure yet. Also while visiting his parents
column5: he had visited a psychologist who advised him to take a few more months of break as it is too early after his divorce to enter a new relationship. He highlighted the job issue for his reason but I personally think that the advice of the psychologist was more important to him as he said I don't want to make a mistake again. Finally he asked me to give him 4-5 month time to make things work. After that we were in contact 2-3 times for just doing some normal favors for each other. Now it has been over 5.5 month and there is no sign from him. I really am not the type of a person who starts the relationship
column6: so I don't want to call him and ask him about his status. I am just wondering that shall I assume it is over? was he some kind of polite at the time he was explaining his situation? I am really confused... ESTJs please help me in understanding him

column4: too emotional + stupid = get TF away from me. I also can't stand people who let other people walk all over them
column5: people who don't stand up for themselves
column6: weak
column7: feeble

Originally Posted by Aspiringwriter   4. Are you comfortable in large groups of people? How many friends do you have? How important is family to you?    I am but I don't really care about large groups and one-on-one is often more fun because it's more meaningful. Also
column9: you can manipulate better one-on-one. Large groups are fun. One-on-one has some point. And I
column11: prefer it to have some point. Most extroverts probably like large groups because they haven't got a hidden agenda like I do. Introverts prefer one-on-one because they don't like large groups and whatever. My reasoning - I'll use either the one-on-one or the large group to my benefit. I like large groups
column13: for fun.      Originally Posted by Aspiringwriter   5. I'm ISTJ- could our types get along? I've never met any before and am curious about the dynamics.    I usually prefer extroverted people but if intelligent enough
column14: an introvert will catch my attention. However
column15: I can't stand people with no social skills
column16: or people who avoid others. I don't like it when you don't communicate at all with the shop assistants or waiters
column17: or if you can't talk to strangers (for whatever reason) because of being shy or avoiding people in general. I value social skills and I like anyone who's got better ones than mine.

column1: ESTJ	This is kind of a two-part question.
ESTJ	What are your thoughts on your ENTJ counterparts?
ESTJ	In what ways do you think you differ from them?

ESTJ	Originally Posted by Nightstorm   This is kind of a two-part question.
ESTJ	What are your thoughts on your ENTJ counterparts?
ESTJ	In what ways do you think you differ from them?
ESTJ	- Curious INFJ    I worked under an ENTJ in my last gig. ENTJ type 3.

ESTJ	Primary difference is he is heavily long term strategical as compared to me. When working I am thinking about short term future-- next couple of years. He's thinking more long term-- next seven to ten years.

ESTJ	He excelled at seeing the overarching strategies. He falteref at designing effective tactical steps to achieve these goals due to analysis paralysis. He started gathering information and suddenly there was never enough info to push him to make a decision. He was also terrible at focusing on the right details. Under stress he would pull out a microscope and try to control everything that didn't actually matter to achieving the goal.

ESTJ	He also had a habit of putting too much responsibility on his employees. This was good and bad: it helped every person in the office take full ownership of their work and be proactive about solving issues themselves when they arose. However

Especially in a more casual enviorment; you can see it in ESTJ "story-time" where an ESTJ will start going on random Si/Ne tangents; ESTJs can often have a really great sense of humor and be quite funny and enjoy creativity (you don't see it as much in ESTJ work mode). I have known some ESTJs to venture into art and creative projects. I think (bad) Ne grips in ESTJs make ESTJs seem *super* paranoid. Never fun to be in the presence of an ESTJ in a non-functioning Te-Ne loop - although it's kind of hilarious. My ESTJ manager will become just completely and utterly scatterbrained

column1: ESTJ	Every ESTJ I've known has hated my Ne (initially); but also loved it. I remember when I started working with my ESTJ manager she would tell people "man this girl asks a lot of questions". She would complain about it initially and I knew she didn't love the amount of questions I asked but at the end of day because of all my questions I would do everything right and cover all my bases (exactly why I do this). I look at every possibility and every situation from different angles so if a situatuon did come up I can react when that situation did come up. Eventually she was using me as example to other staff because I wasn't afraid to ask questions. And because of my questions I was doing everything right. ESTJs only find Ne annoying if there's no follow-through as long as you can prove your competence and it takes a long time for ESTJs to trust anyone so it's not overnight. Always expect some amount grumbles from an ESTJ though when you're talking to them with a lot of Ne (especially in a work enviorment). I've known many ESTJs to apologize for acting too harshly in the moment but don't expect it until later and probrably after you've proven yourself to them. column6: like what is really going on inside your head when you encounter smb like that.    I believe I can help. With less self-aware ESTJ's
column7: inferior Fi suppresses their own feeling based judgments and so they tend to consider that the same in others is also a weakness. It's a projection. They have spent their lives suppressing their feeling based judgements and that has given them success so it becomes a self-repeating cycle of suppression > validation - which then again gets projected to others because they had success with it. Emotions while not Jungian related in terms of psychology similarly also got repressed because repression for them reaps rewards over time ... Then comes the nature of Si where it's mostly projection of what worked for them would work for others - and since repression of emotion worked for them
column8: it'll work for someone else too. Most (if not all) ESTJ's don't have the time or the energy or even desire to understand emotions of others at all because they're so busy repressing all of that F related "stuff" in their own mind. They need to be repressed because if they're not repressed then they get in the way of achieving what they wanted to achieve. My dad is a lot like your mom in that regard. Only after turning 73 has he started somewhat exploring his emotional side
column9: but even then he'll share a few emotional things one day and then go back to his repressive state the next like nothing ever happened. Right now one of my cousins is dying of a stroke (he's only 51) and my dad has no emotion to speak of. None at all. It's clear that he's buried it so deep that it seems like it doesn't even exist - and he probably believes that it doesn't exist for him either.

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by Ariviel   Do ESTJs find emotional people weak or can they strike as cute to them too? column1: ESTJ	(other ESTJs are welcome to answer as well of course
column2: but I guess you don't need an invitation for that..)    I know a lot of people say ESTJ are not very affectionate and kind but I disagree with my experience with a few I know. Which bring me to my question
column3: are ESTJ affectionate and kind to people ingeneral? If not do they just have to be close to the person? And do ESTJ dislike nice people?

column1: ESTJ	Originally Posted by Cuddly_Cactus   I know a lot of people say ESTJ are not very affectionate and kind but I disagree with my experience with a few I know. Which bring me to my question
column2: are ESTJ affectionate and kind to people ingeneral? If not do they just have to be close to the person? And do ESTJ dislike nice people?    Ok
column3: I'm not ESTJ
column4: but I know a number of them.

column1: ESTJ	Usually people say ESTJs are mean and not affectionate
column2: then someone comes in with an exception like "ESTJs aren't mean and not affectionate contrary to popular belief."

column1: ESTJ	It goes back and forth. ESTJs prefer to be more professional in their approach with strangers
column2: not mean
column3: not too nice
column4: just neutral. With people they are close too they can relax and show affection but it is not in ways that are obvious to people who do not know them
column5: some forms of ESTJ affection can be making you the butt of their jokes (this is a way to draw attention to you and pick you out of a group of people to say "Hey
column6: I notice you
column7: and I like you as a person
column8: otherwise I wouldn't be taking the time to say your name let alone make a joke about you.") Super duper forms of affection are not normal for an ESTJ
column9: they can put on a professional smile
column10: they can be polite to strangers just fine but this does not mean much and only is done because it's how one must conduct themselves in public
column11: or to show they were raised right. This whole professional demeanor is dropped with close friends
column12: as they joke more say more crude things and relax.

column1: ESTJ	ESTJs also do not dislike nice people and they appreciate truly kind people
column2: what they find uncomfortable and distrusting is huge displays of flagrant emotion
column3: they may not know why someone is being so favorable towards them or how honest someone is being when they dole out things like "OH MY GOD I LOVE YOUUUUU! OH MY GOD I'VE MISSED YOUUUU." And it's not common for an ESTJ to show those forms of affection. ESTJ forms of affection come more in the form of acts of service. If an ESTJ ever shows concern in your well being or your problems
column4: they care about you to some extent to supply their greatest strength and asset to you
column5: their energy and their time
column6: because ESTJs can be highly scheduled people and do not give their precious time to things that do not matter to them
column7: because they have something more important to do.

column1: ESTJ	If you are seeking warm compassion
column2: ESTJ will respond with professional and neutral responses. So you will be disappointed.

column1: ESTJ	But as far as people close to them
column2: usually these people can range from work buddies who share their work struggles and listen to their work complaints
column3: a stress reliever and sounding board if you will
column4: old time friends they can reminisce with and share those that their worldview
column5: people they can go out with and have a good time drinking a beer with
column6: to people who can help them relax and laugh because they can playfully bring up things that are unordinary and help the ESTJ get out of a serious mind frame and be silly for a few minutes before they get back to work.

column1: ESTJ	With the ESTJs I've known I usually end up being the silly non threatening friend they at first kinda like to keep around
column2: but then start to REALLY like to keep around lol. I've even made my ESTJ boss
column3: who is a pretty intimidating woman
column4: laugh by saying a silly and unusual joke. It seems like a nice treat if the silliness does not distract one from getting work done.

column1: ESTJ	All the ESTJs I've known they've never been super affectionate
column2: even one girl I knew and friends with was not super affectionate
column3: it's more like they are enthusiastic about helping me if I have a goal or a problem
column4: and that's an easy way to see "Wow this person is a real friend!" and it's easy to see they care about you through that enthusiasm. I remember one time I missed my bus and it was driving to a bus stop a mile down the street
column5: my ESTJ friend who dropped me off at my current bus stop
column6: saw that I missed my bus
column7: and he pulled up to me and said "Hey
column8: let's catch that bus." Like some old time movie crime partner lol
column9: I hopped in the car and he raced after that bus
column10: and he didn't feel burdened or anything
column11: he was excited to help even though it had nothing to do with him
column13: no affection or any of that stuff needed (also we are both guys so that's weird lol). I've also had another ESTJ friend who I let stay at my apartment for 2 months
column14: he fixed me lunch for work everyday he stayed there LOL
column16: and he cooked for me and my roommate
column18: we are both guys so it was weird at first but he was happy to do it
column19: and felt like he couldn't stay in my house without contributing something
column22: no extra emotion or affection needed once again
column23: and we are close. I've had another ESTJ friend pay for his own and my plane flight ticket
column24: just because he was excited I agreed to go out of town to an event with him. That to me seems like and ESTJ being "affectionate." But I think with strangers they'd rather be professional
column28: but not super emotionally expressive or accommodating to people they do not know.

column1: ESTJ	I mean I've seen an ESTJ talk about how when his daughter started to distance herself from him when she was in her rebellious teens
column2: he just started to bring her in closer
column3: taking her everywhere with him and trying to keep the relationship strong.

column1: ESTJ	I've also seen an ESTJ cry many times in public about his wife who passed away years ago
column2: and the way he talks about her you can tell he loved her and she was everything to him.

column1: ESTJ	So yea
column2: they are people
column3: like everybody else.

column1: ESTJ	What I honestly think is this
column2: someone will read the extrovert and introvert descriptions
column3: and an extrovert might read the E descriptions through the lens of "this is normal behavior everybody does this." and when they read the I description they see it through the lens of "Oh wow I do that sometimes
column4: that's what that is? Wow I must be an introvert since I do like alone time sometimes." Not realizing that their own surprise at why they might like alone time occasionally is the very thing that exposes them as an extrovert
column5: if alone time is something surprising or "different" or unusual for you
column6: but not really necessary
column7: you are an E.
